title: The Next Frontier for Electric Vehicles: Deep Underground
summary: To improve air quality and reduce emissions, mining companies aim to shift away from diesel equipment. SYDNEY-The next boom in electric vehicles could be the world's mining fleet.

title: Warren Has a (Fantasy) Plan
summary: Her financing and savings ideas for Medicare for All bear no relation to reality.. Now we know why Elizabeth Warren took so long to release the financing details of her Medicare-for-All plan. The 20 pages of explanation she released Friday reveal that she is counting on ideas for cost-savings and new revenue that are a fiscal and health-care fantasy.

title: 'America First'? Kill the Jones Act
summary: Puerto Rico is importing Russian natural gas, due to this outdated law.. Russian natural gas is again being delivered by ship to an American port, according to news reports. Bloomberg says the tanker Catalunya Spirit, carrying fuel from thousands of miles away, was set to arrive in Puerto Rico last week. Such a transaction makes little sense, as the U.S. is the world's largest gas producer.

title: Beto O'Rourke's Shooting Star
summary: His cultural left turn wasn't enough in a field of progressives.. A certain presumptuousness, even willfulness, is essential for anyone who wants to be President, but when does that quality become too much to take? Perhaps we found out with Beto O'Rourke, who chose to run for the nation's highest office after losing a Senate race, but dropped out on Friday having failed to attract much support.

title: Biden Tested in Iowa as Rivals Gain Ground
summary: Buttigieg, Warren and Sanders solidify their poll standings in the first nominating contest. DES MOINES, Iowa-Joe Biden is facing a narrower path to win the first presidential-nominating contest, as a strengthening Pete Buttigieg threatens to cut into his support among centrist Democrats while Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders solidify their hold on the party's left wing.

title: When Things Get Tough, Companies Split Chairman, CEO Roles
summary: From Boeing to WeWork, a record number of big U.S. companies are dividing their leadership roles-often after a crisis. When the crisis at Boeing Co. escalated into calls for replacing Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg, the jet maker's board did the next closest thing: stripped him of his role as chairman.

title: Trump Advisers Pushed Unproven Theory on Ukraine, Documents Show
summary: Flynn, Manafort and others didn't believe Russia acted to help the president, contradicting U.S. findings. President Trump's skepticism of Russian involvement in the 2016 hack of Democrats' emails, and his belief that Ukrainian officials were working to support his opponent, appear to have been fueled in part by senior advisers dating back to that year's presidential campaign, according to FBI interview notes and other documents.

title: Would Tulsi Gabbard's Foreign Policy Work?
summary: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard's derision of the "Bush-Clinton" doctrine would be far less compelling if she used the more accurate term "Wilson/FDR/Truman/Kennedy" doctrine.. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard's derision of the "Bush-Clinton" doctrine would be far less compelling if she used the more accurate term "Wilson/FDR/Truman/Kennedy" doctrine ("I Can Defeat Trump and The Clinton Doctrine," op-ed, Oct. 30). We should also ask the South Koreans what they would have thought of her brand of international relations during the Korean War.

title: Trump Takes the Long View on China Trade
summary: There's a lot to not like about President Trump, but he's the only one who's had the guts to stand up to China and try to stop its bad-faith games.. Regarding your editorial "Adam Smith's Revenge" (Oct. 31): It distresses me to read your take on the cooling effect the trade "war" with China is having on our otherwise booming economy, as if the dampening effect of the trade war with China was something that needed curing right away. There's a bigger picture to be considered here. It's clear to me that China has long been a bad actor in the world of commerce-stealing technology and forcing corporations to divulge proprietary secrets as the price for limited, temporary access to its markets. Not wanting to make waves, we've allowed it to happen in our zeal for cheap goods and access to that market. Frankly, we've been naive and China has eaten our lunch.

title: Time to Ditch Overly Broad Ethnic Classes
summary: The implication that "Asian-American" should be parsed into more accurate subdivisions for advantage in the American diversity-thru-discrimination sweepstakes could apply to "whites" as well.. François Melese's comments about Asian-Americans apply equally to European-Americans, whose ancestors originated anywhere from Portugal to Russia or Greece to Norway ("'Asian-American' Is Too Broad to Be Useful," Letters, Oct. 30). There are also stark cultural differences in culture, history, language, religion, etc., among the English, Irish, Scottish, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Swedish, Finnish, Norwegian, Danish, German, Polish, Russian, Romanian, Italian, Greek and Hungarian peoples, not to mention Catalans, Provençals and others seeking their own national identities.

title: iGeners Are Reading Less And Writing Less Well, Too
summary: In the last American Time Use Survey, 15-24-year-olds racked up only six minutes a day of leisure reading despite having five-plus hours of free time.. Prof. Jack Falvey thinks people are too hard on kids these days ("In Defense of iGen," Oct. 25). Haven't kids always shirked reading and avoided history? In fact, he says, "Some iGeners can find their way around to places and things you and I can't imagine." He notes, "They see things you and I often miss, and they write about them very well."

title: Bias Response Teams and Absence of Responsibility
summary: "Who do you want to be the boss of how you feel? You or someone else?". Your editorial "Adios, Bias Response Team" (Oct. 31) brings back memories of my daughter at age 6 or 7. She came into the house crying and crawled onto my lap. Two neighbor children said something that made her feel bad. After drying her tears, I asked her if she wanted other children to control how she felt, and told her she could choose to not let what someone else said make her feel bad: "Who do you want to be the boss of how you feel? You or someone else?" She perked up and said, "I want to be the boss of me!" Out the door she ran.

title: Earnings Tide Lifts Most Stocks
summary: Investors are getting a more positive picture of American corporations' health than that painted by analysts in buildup to earnings season. Earnings are making their biggest splash in the stock market in years.

title: Follow Michael Crichton's Rule
summary: The late writer warned about bending to social pressure instead of heeding evidence.. "Jurassic Park" and "Westworld," from the brilliant mind of Michael Crichton, aren't real. But neither are a lot of things that pass for arguments these days. Crichton, who died in 2008, gave a lecture at Caltech in 2003 titled "Aliens Cause Global Warming." In his words, it was about the "uneasy relationship between hard science and public policy" but I took away a lot more. Relax, this column isn't about climate change.

title: Don't Slay the Chilean Puma
summary: A rewrite of the constitution would destroy opportunity for the poor.. When Chilean President Sebastián Piñera canceled plans to host the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Santiago this month, he called it "a difficult decision that has caused us a lot of pain."

title: A Canceled Kanye Begins a Hymn
summary: Woke culture demands penance but doesn't forgive.. Kanye West has had it with "cancel culture." He's sick of the woke mobs that take people down for what they deem transgressions. "I've been canceled," the hip-hop artist told a Los Angeles radio station this month. "I've been canceled before they had cancel culture." His sins include sporting a MAGA hat and disparaging Taylor Swift, but also, more seriously, calling slavery a "choice" and chanting misogynistic lyrics.

title: 'The Mysterious Affair at Olivetti' Review: Keys to a Cold War Puzzle
summary: Soon after an Italian company developed one of the ﬁrst desktop computers, the ﬁrm foundered and two of its leaders died suddenly.. If a predilection for conspiracy theories has recently spread to the mainstream of American life, many countries are, so to speak, way ahead of us, and one with a notably robust appetite is Italy. So keen is the Italian taste for dietrologia (literally, "behindology") that it seems part of the national character, like the passion for espresso and soccer.

title: The Truth About Income Inequality
summary: The census fails to account for taxes and most welfare payments, painting a distorted picture.. Never in American history has the debate over income inequality so dominated the public square, with Democratic presidential candidates and congressional leaders calling for massive tax increases and federal expenditures to redistribute the nation's income. Unfortunately, official measures of income inequality, the numbers being debated, are profoundly distorted by what the Census Bureau chooses to count as household income.

title: Trump Reverses Obama's Anti-Religious Decree
summary: No more discrimination against Catholics and evangelical Protestants in adoption services.. Pro-life Americans often get criticized for focusing too much on babies in the womb and not enough on those who've been born. Yet countless evangelical Christians devote their lives to foster care, adoption and similar services for vulnerable children. As born-again Christians, we have been adopted by Christ and have a special obligation to those who need a mother and father.

title: The Clinton Impeachment Was Fair
summary: We were on the House prosecution team. Unlike Pelosi and Schiff, we safeguarded due process.. Tensions ran high 20 years ago as we stood in the well of the Senate before Chief Justice William Rehnquist, all 100 senators and the nation. As House impeachment managers, we presented our case against President Clinton. We were somber but confident, knowing that we had afforded Mr. Clinton every due-process right to defend himself.

title: Actually, the Problem Is 'Humansplaining'
summary: People of both sexes imagine they're the go-to authority on-well, anything they care to be.. My soul quavers each time I read a lachrymose Twitter broadside about some dude in a Starbucks line who said one too many things about coffee beans and now he's been tossed to the internet wolves for "mansplaining."

title: California's Maria Fire Half Contained
summary: All other large fires monitored by Cal Fire were 76% or more contained by Sunday morning. California firefighters made progress over the weekend in controlling destructive fires that have engulfed the state.

title: Developing Wind Farm in New York Is No Breeze
summary: Resume Subscription. LOWVILLE, N.Y.-Calvin Roes can see wind turbines peaking over the hill west of his dairy farm, and more if he looks north into the neighboring town. He is frustrated that a new development is stalled.

title: In Chile, Peaceful Protests Turn Violent by Night
summary: President Sebastian Piñera last week canceled two international summits as authorities lose control of capital's streets. SANTIAGO, Chile-As nighttime falls, the peaceful protesters who have taken over the streets of this capital stream home, shopkeepers quickly close businesses, and young men with bandannas covering their faces emerge to wreak havoc.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Factory Orders, Trade Data from the U.S. and China, Bank of England Rate Decision
summary: Tuesday's trade data from the Commerce Department is the highlight of the week.

title: Netanyahu Prods U.S. to Stay Focused on Iran
summary: Worries grow among Israeli officials who consider U.S. responses to recent Iranian moves as muted.

title: Young Kenyans Dominate in New York City Marathon
summary: Geoffrey Kamworor wins men's race; Joyciline Jepkosgei takes women's title. A new generation of champions was crowned in Manhattan on Sunday, as two young Kenyan runners won the New York City Marathon.

title: Brexit Can Wait. Boris Johnson Has Other Problems: Crosswalks, Tree Trimming
summary: Resume Subscription. UXBRIDGE, England -- When Deborah King spots a problem in this middle class West London suburb, she fires off an email to her local lawmaker. There was the time a water pipe burst in a road nearby. Or when the 59-year-old was inconvenienced by people vaping on the bus. "He doesn't seem to reply," she says.

title: Trump Allies Ramp Up Efforts to Unmask Whistleblower
summary: Some GOP lawmakers and conservative media outlets have sought to reveal a person they believe is behind the complaint even as other witnesses have supported its central findings. WASHINGTON-Some Republican lawmakers want to out the whistleblower whose complaint set off the impeachment inquiry and are amplifying articles in conservative media outlets that assert theories about the person's identity.

title: 'Terminator: Dark Fate' Fails to Revive Cyborg Franchise
summary: Newest Terminator film makes $29 million in the U.S. and Canada, while Harriet Tubman biopic 'Harriet' collected a healthy $12 million. LOS ANGELES-Thirty-five years ago, the Terminator proclaimed, "I'll be back." This weekend-yet again-he made good on that vow, but not many moviegoers seemed to care.

title: Trump Threatens to Cut California Wildfire Funds
summary: President again calls on state's governor to 'clean' forest floors to help prevent the spread of fires. NEW YORK-President Trump threatened to cut off federal funding to assist California in fighting wildfires as the state grapples with the fallout from blazes that have led to evacuations and power outages.

title: The Key to Electric Cars Is Batteries. One Chinese Firm Dominates the Industry.
summary: Resume Subscription. SHANGHAI-A little-known Chinese company has become the world's biggest maker of electric vehicle batteries.

title: Judge Blocks Health-Care Requirement for Immigrants
summary: A new policy would have required new immigrants to show proof of health insurance or the means to afford it. A federal court has blocked the Trump administration from implementing a policy that would require new immigrants to demonstrate they have health care or are able to afford it.

title: Breeders' Cup Ends With Another Horse Death at Santa Anita
summary: Mongolian Groom suffered a catastrophic injury to his left hind leg in the stretch of the Classic. There have now been 37 fatalities at the facility since Dec. 26.. ARCADIA, Calif.-The Breeders' Cup on Saturday ended in a tragic fashion that could have major consequences for the horse racing industry, as Mongolian Groom suffered a catastrophic injury to his left hind leg in the stretch of the $6 million Classic at Santa Anita Park and was euthanized.

title: Airbnb Spends Millions to Fight Jersey City Ballot Measure
summary: Backers of tougher rules cite quality of life and jump in housing costs; Airbnb says it has helped boost local tourism economy. Jersey City voters will soon choose whether to beef up regulations on short-term rental properties marketed by companies like Airbnb Inc. in what has become a bitter, multimillion-dollar standoff between the company and its critics.

title: Iran Marks Anniversary of U.S. Embassy Siege as Jailed Americans Await Thaw
summary: Detained foreigners are collateral in damaged relationship with the West, their fate hinging on powers agreeing to negotiate geopolitical issues.

title: Virginia Election Offers Pre-2020 Test for Parties
summary: Entire legislature is up for grabs. Tuesday's legislative election in Virginia has drawn high-profile campaigners and millions of dollars in out-of-state donations, in a critical test of voter enthusiasm and party momentum ahead of the nationwide 2020 elections.

title: Younger Workers Report Seeing More Discrimination
summary: Different generations experience sexism, racism and ageism at varying levels in office, new poll shows. American workers under the age of 35 are more likely to see and experience discrimination at the office, according to a new poll, indicating how different generations can view the same behavior.

title: Hong Kong Politician Attacked, as Violent Protests Continue
summary: District Councilor Andrew Chiu is latest in a string of pro-democracy figures to be attacked. HONG KONG-A pro-democracy politician was among the victims of a brutal attack during the 22nd weekend of protests in Hong Kong, as the city becomes increasingly mired in a cycle of violence.

title: Are We in a Recession? Experts Agree: Ask Claudia Sahm
summary: Sahm rule is reassuring to economists looking for new ideas on stimulus when interest rates are already low. Two of the biggest challenges of fighting a recession are knowing when you're in one and deciding what to do next. When economic data weaken, it's impossible to know in real time whether it's a blip or something more prolonged. The official declaration usually comes a year or more after a recession starts.

title: A Filmmaker Rips His Material From the Headlines
summary: Scott Z. Burns, whose new movie, 'The Report,' is about a Senate investigation, transforms real-life events into popcorn dramas. Some screenwriters find their source material in comic books. Scott Z. Burns found his in the 2014 Senate Intelligence Committee Report on Torture-and turned it into a movie.

title: AirPods Pro Review: Big Improvements at a 'Pro' Price
summary: Best of all the upgrades might be that AirPods Pro stay in your ears-and for $249, they'd better. When AirPod zombies don't acknowledge what you are saying, one of two things is happening:

title: Investors Should Watch Out for an Unbalanced Economy
summary: The Fed's third rate cut this year is in response to a problem it can't really solve. When one part of the economy stumbles and another does rather well, the perfect policy would be support the laggard while holding back the rest to keep growth balanced. Instead the Federal Reserve has been forced to support the household sector even as consumption remains strong, while there is little or nothing it can do to help companies faced with near-record levels of global economic uncertainty.

title: Impeachment Increasingly Divides Americans by Party
summary: Some 49% in Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll would remove Mr. Trump from office, with 46% opposing impeachment.

title: Getting Fit Meant Sink or Swim for an Ex-NFL Star
summary: Resume Subscription. Former Cleveland Browns offensive lineman Joe Thomas fueled his NFL workouts with 10,000 calories a day. Now, he would need about five days to eat that much. After retiring in March 2018, Mr. Thomas radically overhauled his diet and exercise.

title: Crude Exporters Prepare for Sustained High Shipping Costs
summary: The U.S. blacklisting of the Cosco tankers set tanker freight rates on fire, but maritime fundamentals will keep prices high. Crude oil exporters and users probably should get used to high shipping costs.

title: The Photographers Who Walk Into the California Fires
summary: Meet a crew of photojournalists who risk their lives during summer and fall months to tell the world the story of these natural disasters. Geyserville, Calif.

title: Photos: Inside the Fire Zone
summary: A sampling of photographs taken by Noah Berger and Josh Edelson of California's wildfires. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Small Caps Absent in Stocks' March to Records
summary: Generally considered riskier, small-company shares have stalled amid weaker economic data, recession fears. The S&P 500 has surged 22% this year, setting 16 record closes along the way. Meanwhile, the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks has been left behind.

title: Saudi Aramco Launches Long-Awaited IPO
summary: Shares in the oil giant are expected to begin trading on the Saudi stock market in December. Saudi state oil giant Aramco officially launched its initial public offering on Sunday, setting in motion what is expected to be the world's largest ever share sale, even as questions remain over the company's value.

title: Small Caps Absent in Stocks' March to Records
summary: Generally considered riskier, small-company shares have stalled amid weaker economic data, recession fears. The S&P 500 has surged 22% this year, setting 16 record closes along the way. Meanwhile, the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks has been left behind.

title: Saudi Aramco Launches Long-Awaited IPO
summary: Shares in the oil giant are expected to begin trading on the Saudi stock market in December. Saudi state oil giant Aramco officially launched its initial public offering on Sunday, setting in motion what is expected to be the world's largest ever share sale, even as questions remain over the company's value.

title: People Are Staying in Their Homes Longer-a Big Reason for Slow Sales
summary: Resume Subscription. U.S. homeowners are staying in their residences much longer than before, keeping a glut of housing inventory off the market, which helps explain why home sales have been sputtering.

title: Prosecutors Face Complex Path to Charging Boeing Over 737 MAX
summary: To bring a successful criminal case, investigators must prove Boeing repeatedly concealed or ignored engineering problems. Federal prosecutors would face a daunting challenge in mounting a criminal case against Boeing Co. or its employees, legal experts said, even with evidence showing workers sounded alarms about the 737 MAX's safety and a company pilot's chat messages suggesting he misled regulators.

title: Trump Greeted With Boos-and Cheers-at UFC Event
summary: President spent Saturday night sitting cageside at mixed martial-arts fight at New York's Madison Square Garden. NEW YORK-President Trump briefly escaped Washington, a city where the sparring is often metaphorical, to witness a night of fighting that was decidedly real. And, occasionally, bloody.

title: Small Businesses Brace for Hurdles in Shell-Company Bills
summary: Proposals in Congress would require most limited-liability companies to identify their true owners. Small businesses are assessing the potential costs of complying with requirements under proposals in both chambers of Congress aimed at limiting the use of anonymous shell companies.

title: A 'Zombie' Chinese Deal for an American Insurer Staggers Toward the Unknown
summary: Chinese conglomerate's planned $2.7 billion takeover of Genworth Financial is one of the longest engagements in deal history.

title: Peugeot's Bold CEO to Take the Wheel in Deal With Fiat Chrysler
summary: Carlos Tavares, who would head merged firm, cut costs at the French car maker; 'we are not market-share addicts'. PARIS-Carlos Tavares stunned the auto world when he left his post as heir apparent to Carlos Ghosn at the globe-spanning Renault-Nissan alliance six years ago and then took the reins of struggling rival Peugeot, which sold relatively few cars outside Europe.

title: California Firefighters Embrace New Technology
summary: State has had no highly destructive wildfires yet this year, which officials attribute in part to better techniques. California has battled some of its biggest wildfires this year with a new weapon: a plane outfitted with infrared sensors that can see through smoke to plot the blazes' perimeters and transmit the coordinates to firefighters in real-time.

title: Malian Government Says 54 Dead in Attack on Army
summary: Attack is the second major assault against the country's armed forces in a month. Jihadists attacked the Malian military near the border with Niger, leaving at least 53 soldiers and one civilian dead, in the second major assault against the country's armed forces in a month, the government said Saturday.
